title: Is it possible to clear a line of credit and modify a loan when you file bankruptcy?
question: we have a home loan with bank of america 703,000 and line of credit also with bank of america about 200,000 .we stop pay both of them about a year ago because we had a hard time (we work in real estate and constraction) We did try to modify the loans ,but it was with a scam company we did not recive notice of sale yet ,but the lawyer that we working with now ask us to do bankruptcy and he will modify the first loan and clear the line of credit he said it will work for sure .what do you think about it .please give us your advice .
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers:
You can do what is called a "cram down" or "lien strip" on your 2nd mortgage, assuming that the 2nd mortgage is completely underwater. This only applies to chapter 13 bankruptcies. Most loan modification reviews are closed upon the filing of bankruptcy.

Of course, there are many many other questions that need to be answered, i.e. what is your income, what other debts do you have, etc...

If you'd like to discuss your bankruptcy options, feel free to contact me. http://www.pacificpremierlaw.com

A second mortgage can be eliminated or stripped in a chapter 13 bankruptcy. A lawyer would need to review your complete financial situation to see if you qualify as there are limitations. Click the link below and you can read some comprehensive information on chapter 13 bankruptcy that will give you a better idea of what to expect in a chapter 13 bankruptcy.

If the home is worth less then the first mortgage then second mortgages or secured lines of credit can be discharged. if the line of credit is unsecured then it can be discharged. you should be working with a bankruptcy attorney in your area on these issues. Modifications can be done while you are in bankruptcy.
